intro: Haplopappus lanuginosus subsp. andersonii, commonly known as the Anderson's hairy hawksbeard, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and distinctive foliage. The plant typically grows in arid and semi-arid environments, such as rocky soils and open plains. Its leaves are covered in fine, soft hairs, giving it a fuzzy appearance. The subspecies is distinguished by its unique morphological traits, including the structure of its pappus and the coloration of its flowers.
